description: Listed only by Wedgwood, who says: Kammer - In old German organs a term signifying that the stop to the name of which it was prefixed was tuned to �Kammerton� (chamber tone), a tone in pitch below �Chorton� (choir tone). Such stops (Kammerflöte, Kammergedackt, etc.) were tuned a tone lower than the rest of the organ and used for instrumental accompaniment. Examples Kammerton-Gedackt 8', Oberwerk; Brandenburger Dom (Liebfrauenkirche), Brandenburg, Germany; Joachim Wagner, 1733-36. This is the only known example. Bibliography Wedgwood[1]: Kammer. FOOTER Original site compiled by Edward L. Stauff. For educational use only. Kammerflote.html - Last updated 30 May 2000. Home Full Index
